image.altText: A whitish-blue iceberg floating in grey water.

items.synopsis: Funding and operational issues at the Australian Antarctic Division are having a "catastrophic" impact on critical research and damaging the organisation's international reputation, a Senate inquiry is told.

title.children: Antarctic researchers concerned by 'catastrophic' funding and operational decisions

image.altText: An older man peers out his window. His chocolate brown cavoodle is on his lap and looks directly at the camera

items.synopsis: A Tasmanian man who was ramped for more than six hours says the state's hospitals are "broken", as unions claim it's the worst they've seen

title.children: When David was rushed to ED, he didn't expect to end up in a hallway

image.altText: A globe centred on Australia showing sea surface temperature patterns in red and blue with a time scale labelled July 2023

items.synopsis: It’s the phenomenon behind some of Australia’s hottest, driest years, and climate change could be making it more extreme. Here’s why that doesn’t guarantee catastrophe this year — or in the future.

title.children: An El Niño could be declared as early as next week: This is what it looks like when it forms

items.synopsis: It was a sunny start to the week but from today a polar air mass will sweep over south-east Australia, causing temperatures to plummet by as much as 15 degrees Celsius in 24 hours.

title.children: Hail, snow and gales to replace spring heat in a battle of the seasons

image.altText: A woman in a yellow jacket, a woman in a navy jacket sit on a green bench seat while a man stands and shouts

items.synopsis: The heated discussion over why Qatar Airways' bid to increase flights to Australia was rejected has left the government juggling excess political baggage, writes Brett Worthington.

title.children: Just 11 seconds of answers preceded the third question on Qatar saga — and then all hell broke lose

image.altText: Close up of Alan Joyce

items.synopsis: Alan Joyce reportedly jets off with a substantial amount of cash and Qantas shares in his portfolio — but valid questions are being asked about whether he is entitled to all of it.

title.children: Alan Joyce leaves Qantas with millions in the bank, but his final scandal as CEO has slashed his last payout

image.altText: A sign saying emergency pointing towards a colourful building.

items.synopsis: Tasmanians are being urged seek "alternative healthcare options" to take pressure off the state's two main hospitals. Health unions say the situation is "the worst it's ever been".

title.children: 'People will die': Dire warnings from health unions as Tasmanians urged to stay away from hospitals amid surge

image.altText: Natalie Sinclair sitting at a table, reaching towards bottles of Hysone and Hydrocortisone.

items.synopsis: The drug Natalie Sinclair takes to keep her alive is among hundreds of medications that have been in short supply in Australia, but advocates fear stockholding laws for suppliers are having little impact on the ground.

title.children: 'Pretty terrifying': Advocates say medicine shortages still an issue, despite stockholding rules

image.altText: A dam and rolling green hills.

items.synopsis: Researchers identify thousands of locations for potential micro-pumped-hydro energy storage across rural Australia, using pre-existing farm dams and rivers.

title.children: Australia is pockmarked with small dams. With a little tweak, many could be turned into 'batteries'

image.altText: the front of a house and carport, with the ocean seen behind it

items.synopsis: The rise of short-term holiday rentals like Airbnb and Stayz have changed the way we travel, but they've also faced backlash over concerns they're driving rents up and exacerbating housing shortages in cities around the world.

title.children: How much are short-term rentals really impacting Australia's housing crisis?

image.altText: Relaxed anonymous male teenager texting on mobile phone. His face is obscured by his hands and mobile in front of him.

items.synopsis: Recently emojis have landed some people in legal trouble in courts around the world. So what constitutes crossing the line?

title.children: Texted emojis landed these people in legal trouble. Here's how to avoid it happening to you

image.altText: Man stands in front of a large drum of cable.

items.synopsis: The Tasmanian government details the $1.7 billion reason for downgrading the Marinus Link electricity interconnector from two to one cables, but opposition parties say many questions about costs remain unanswered.

title.children: Less than a year on, undersea cable project blows out by almost $2b

image.altText: A smiling man wearing a suit embraces a woman wearing a football uniform

items.synopsis: National Court prosecutors confirm Jenni Hermoso has filed a formal complaint about suspended Spanish soccer boss Luis Rubiales's decision to kiss her after last month's World Cup final in Sydney.

title.children: Spanish soccer star Hermoso files legal complaint over World Cup kiss

image.altText: two womensmiling into the camera with a wall of art behind them

items.synopsis: Almost $40 million will be invested in eating disorder services in Queensland after demand for treatment spikes during the pandemic.

title.children: Lisa first came to an eating disorder service aged 16, as a patient. Now she works there

image.altText: An aerial view of houses with red roofs and a big tree in the middle.

items.synopsis: Sydney is losing thousands of workers to Melbourne and Brisbane because of high housing costs, contributing to a $10-billion economic loss to the city each year, a report has found.

title.children: Sydney's shortage of affordable housing has $10b hidden costs, report finds

image.altText: A close up of a heat pack being held against somebody's body.

items.synopsis: It follows pressure from endometriosis sufferers and the opposition to set up clinics in those locations, after 20 others were established around the country earlier in the year.

title.children: Federal government expands pelvic pain clinics into Adelaide and Western Sydney

image.altText: An historic paddle wheeler emerges from the brown water of the Thomson River, with salvage crews on pontoons and machinery.

items.synopsis: Harnesses and floaties have been used in a major operation to resurface the 99-year-old paddle wheeler.

title.children: Pride of the Murray resurfaces after six months at the bottom of an outback river

image.altText: William Tyrrell's former foster parents, with faces blurred, are seen during a break at the Parramatta Local Court

items.synopsis: William Tyrrell's foster mother blamed the pressure of a police investigation for her alleged abuse towards a different child, a court has heard.

title.children: 'You're a bad mother': Court hears more recordings of alleged abuse by Tyrrell foster mother

image.altText: A film photograph of a young woman wearing a RAAF uniform and smiling.

items.synopsis: After almost 40 years, a man has been charged with murder over the disappearance of 21-year-old Debra Campbell, who went missing from her home in Melbourne's south-east in 1984.

title.children: Police charge man with murder over decades-old Melbourne cold case

image.altText: A cyclist is silhouetted by the bright golden sunset.

items.synopsis: Earth has sweltered through its hottest northern-hemisphere summer ever measured, with a record-warm August capping a season of brutal and deadly temperatures, according to the World Meteorological Organization.

title.children: This August was the hottest ever recorded, UN's weather agency says

image.altText: Joko Widodo, seen from side profile, sits at a desk with his hands folded and headphones on

items.synopsis: Australia brought an "open for business" message to this week's gathering of South-East Asian leaders at the ASEAN summit, but questions about the future of the bloc are already stirring.

title.children: Two major players were missing from ASEAN, sparking questions over its relevance

image.altText: Man in red glasses and blue shirt

items.synopsis: Former ACCC chair Allan Fels says BlueScope deserved its record penalty for attempted cartel behaviour, but warns some companies may factor potential fines into business models — unless they are much higher.

title.children: Former ACCC boss applauds record BlueScope fine for attempted price fixing, calls for higher deterrents

image.altText: A composite image of a woman in a red jacket and an airplane with the word Qatar on it.

items.synopsis: Federal Transport Minister Catherine King rejected a bid by Qatar Airways to introduce an additional 28 weekly flights into major capital cities on the same day she signed a letter to five Australian women who were invasively strip-searched at a Qatari airport.

title.children: Minister rejected Qatar Airways bid same day she signed letter to women strip-searched at Qatari airport

image.altText: Three men in military uniforms and face masks sit on a tank on Russian street at night. The tank bears the letter Z in red.

items.synopsis: A proscription order will ban people in the UK from being "actively involved" in the group or displaying its logo, the defence secretary says.

title.children: UK to ban Russia's Wagner Group, declaring it a 'terrorist organisation'

image.altText: Burned cars are seen at the site of a Russian military strike.

items.synopsis: A Russian attack on a city in eastern Ukraine kills at least 17 people as US Secretary of State Antony Blinken visits Kyiv to offer support for its counteroffensive against Russian forces.

title.children: Attack on busy market in east Ukraine kills 17 people

image.altText: a man smiling sitting next to a woman wearing a wedding dress

items.synopsis: Jordan Fineanganofo now faces several other charges relating to incidents that allegedly occurred over an 18-hour period before the Sydney paramedic was stabbed.

title.children: Man charged over Sydney paramedic murder allegedly assaulted woman day before

image.altText: A large, dark-coloured bull in a pen.

items.synopsis: The sellers had listed Shady with a reserve of $6,000 and say they still can't quite believe the result of the auction in NSW.

title.children: Australian bull sets world record price with 'mind-blowing' $150k sale

image.altText: A space rocket launch vehicle on a rocky island, the picture is taken across the water from the mainland

items.synopsis: Japan is aiming to become the fifth country to land a spacecraft on the lunar surface, with the launch of a low-cost "Moon sniper" that will test precision-landing technology designed to further Tokyo's space goals.

title.children: Japan's 'Moon sniper' to test precision landing

image.altText: A Melbourne AFL captain smiles and high-fives teammates as they gather to celebrate a goal.

items.synopsis: With the AFL finals set to begin, Andrew McGarry runs the rule over the eight contenders and analyses their strengths as well as the weaknesses that may stand in the way of a premiership win.

title.children: Why each team can — and can't — win the AFL flag in 2023

image.altText: An Aboriginal flag in the foreground, Parliament House in the background

items.synopsis: Representatives from a range of peak bodies have travelled to Canberra and spoken with government and crossbench members about the need for a respectful referendum debate, but the ABC understands opposition members have so far refused meetings.

title.children: Coalition members refuse meeting with mental health experts ahead of Voice referendum

image.altText: A over the shoulder shot of a woman whose back is towards the camera, looking at an old vacant church building.

items.synopsis: A woman says she feels "devastated" after vandals caused about $15,000 worth of damage to the 153-year-old church she is renovating into an Airbnb.

title.children: Vandals trash historical church being renovated into Airbnb

image.altText: Kim Jong Un and Vladimir Putin side by side.

items.synopsis: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un may soon meet with Russian President Vladimir Putin. Here's what each world leader stands to gain from each other, and what it could mean for Russia's war in Ukraine.

title.children: Money for munitions is the likely end game between Putin and Kim

image.altText: ACT Chief Police Officer Neil Gaughan.

items.synopsis: Police patrolling Canberra's nightlife precincts are being told to change how they respond to witnessing drug use, ahead of next month's nation-leading decriminalisation laws coming into effect.

title.children: 'They're going to see people take coke': Top cop says ACT police are changing their attitudes to drugs ahead of decriminalisation

image.altText: Promo image of a line chart showing housing costs broken down by income.

items.synopsis: Housing costs are at record highs, and we can show you who is bearing the brunt of the crisis.

title.children: Where you sit on this chart determines your level of housing stress

image.altText: A close up of Newell Convers Wyeth's painting Ramona, frontispiece illustration (Señora Gonzaga Moreno and Ramona)

items.synopsis: The owner joked that it might have been a "real painting" when she bought it, but an internet search proved fruitless. Six years later, a Facebook post changed all that.

title.children: A woman bought this painting in a US op shop for $6. It's expected to fetch $385,000
